text: it's a fall so it's time to cook with
apples I always get really excited this
time of year because even though you can
have apples all year round
they really are seasonal and there's so
much better in the fall today's recipe
is apple strudel and it's a very simple
strudel using puff pastry for the dough
instead of making strudel dough which is
time-consuming so you'll need three
pounds of the apples you can use gala or
Fuji which is an unusual Apple to bake
with but they hold their shape really
really nicely if you want to know more
about how to choose an apple for any
given dish
check out Thomas's video and kitchen
conundrums on how to choose an apple
he'll tell you everything that you need
to know cut your apples into thin slices
right before you're ready to cook them
so they don't just color there's no
lemon juice in here to keep them from
discoloring and these apples are going
to be pre cooked so that everything
comes together really quickly so I'm
going to saute these have a pretty large
skillet available and melt three
tablespoons of butter you know what else
is pretty cool about this recipe there's
only five ingredients the apples have a
great balance of sweetness and acidity
so you don't need any lemon juice when
your butter is melted save one
tablespoon you're going to brush your
pastry when you form your scheudle so
just set that aside for a few minutes
then add your APIs to the pan
along with a half a teaspoon of cinnamon
and a half a cup of granulated sugar I
like this as an alternative to apple pie
for Thanksgiving I mean not that you
need an alternative but this is actually
quite a bit easier than making a
traditional apple pie and I'm all about
making things that are delicious but
also really easy to accomplish so that
you don't get stressed out cook your
apples stirring around every once in a
while until they soften and break down
just a little bit but don't lose their
shape about 15 minutes when the apples
have cooked down you need to cool them
down so what I like to do is put them on
a baking sheet spread them out as thinly
as possible let them cool a little bit
first and then you can put them in the
refrigerator this needs to cool
completely so you could do this a day or
two in advance if you wanted to just
once it was cool transfer it to a
container that's airtight so it doesn't
get any weird flavors in the fridge and
then you can shape and form and bake
your studio when your apples have
chilled you can assemble your strudel
take one sheet of puff pastry from a
seventeen and a half ounce package and
unfold it onto a lightly floured work
surface can get a little crazy if it
gets too warm so just throw back in the
fridge if it does it needs to be about
12 by 14 my hand spans about eight so I
usually just use that as a guide I'm not
overly particular I don't know if you
knew that about me you don't want to
have too much flour attached though so
dust it off as you're going along but
you'll need some of course so it doesn't
stick but you don't want to overdo it
this is looking good have ready a baking
sheet and you want to put this on your
baking sheet and get it back into the
refrigerator just to chill a little bit
it doesn't have to be for too long just
a few minutes
here's the dough chilled take your
cooled apples and spread them over the
center you want to leave like a 1-inch
border on either side and then fill the
center with the apples the apples really
do need to be completely cool for this
otherwise they're just going to melt
your puff pastry which is full of butter
and that will not be pretty it'll get
all gummy and it won't bake up nicely
leave one inch on either side and then
you just fold the dough in just fold one
edge up there's some flour on there you
can brush it off a nice dry pastry brush
is great for this and then the second
side fold over the other side I can like
a little envelope then what you do is
you turn the whole package over so this
is gonna get sealed as it bakes so just
go for it turn it over you can fold the
ends under just a little bit to seal it
and then for golden it'll light from
this brush with that one tablespoon of
butter that you reserved and then make
some slits in the top for the steam to
escape while it's cooking so four nice
slits on the top and then sprinkle with
a little bit of sugar about two
tablespoons is plenty have your oven
preheating to 400 degrees and bake until
it's golden brown and bubbling 35 to 40
minutes allow your strudel to cool for
like 10 minutes you want to serve it
warm but you could rewarm it if you
wanted to and then slice and serve if
you really want to gild the lily whisk
together some confectioner sugar and
milk and drizzle it over the top as a

need to I think you're going to love it
just the way it is smells like fall
